awd_titl_txt: Excitation and Ionization in Atomic Collision Processes --- General Theory and Accurate Numerical Calculations
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports a theoretical program to examine in detail collisions of photons (light), electrons, and other charged particles with atoms and ions.  Highly sophisticated numerical methods and computer programs will be developed and then applied to perform benchmark calculations, whose results will be compared with data from state-of-the-art experiments currently being performed in various laboratories worldwide.  
 
This project provides accurate atomic data, which are needed in many applications, such as modeling plasmas for the lighting industry, processes in planetary atmospheres, and the physics of stars and lasers.  In addition, a deeper understanding of highly correlated processes on the submicroscopic atomic scale will be gained. Of particular interest are processes in ultrashort intense laser fields, at a time scale that allows for the study, and the manipulation, of chemical processes.

por.por_cntn:
We perform high-precision calculations for charged-particle (electrons, ions) and photon (light) collisions with atoms, ions, and small molecules. The corresponding experiments can involve steady-state setups as well as short-pulse intense-field lasers.  In some cases, new algorithms are being developed, with particular emphasis on taking advantage of modern computational resources such as the massively parallel computing platforms of supercomputers. [We have been very successful in obtaining supercomputer access through the TeraGrid/XSEDE allocation process.] In addition to the numerical calculations, we also describe the experiments in general terms, trying to interpret the results and extract the physically useful information.

We have obtained excellent in agreement with experiment in some cases, but found others where significantly more work is required.  We published many papers and several book contributions, and we also presented our results through invited and contributed talks at international scientific conferences and colloquia at other institutions, both in the US and abroad.

We provided extensive cross-section datasets to many users who are interested in plasma modeling.  These cross sections are now available to the general public through various databases.

In addition to the P.I., one post-doctoral researcher funded through this grant and another funded through a different project were involved in this work. The post-doctoral researchers significantly improved their skills in general atomic physics as well as the numerical implementation of sophisticated algorithms, including parallel computing.  They also developed teaching skills by independently teaching undergraduate physics majors (in exchange for partial salary support from Drake University). Furthermore, four undergraduate students were/are trained in the field and prepared for graduate school.  One of them is now at the University of Colorado at Boulder, and another one went to the University of California at Davis, where he has the opportunity to work at Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory.  This student was selected to present his work in the Special Undergraduate Session at the 2010 DAMOP in Houston, TX. Two more students started working with us two and one year ago, respectively. Generally the undergraduates working on the project are being heavily sought after by excellent graduate schools through summer schools and REU opportunities.
